answers: being pressed to death (or Peine forte et dure, crushed to death, or equivalents)
parts: Name these prosecutions in colonial Massachusetts in which twenty men and women were executed for allegedly consorting with the devil.

This Puritan minister and scientist supported the Salem Witch Trials, but cautioned against relying on spectral evidence. This man’s father Increase opposed the Trials while President of Harvard University.

During the peak of the trials, Giles Corey was accused of being a warlock, and after refusing to enter a plea, was executed in this manner. Corey’s final words while being killed in this way were “more weight.”
This Category 4 storm stalled over Texas and Louisiana in late August, causing massive damage and dumping upwards of 50 inches of rain on the greater Houston area.
Before making landfall in Florida, Hurricane Irma caused catastrophic damage on this Caribbean island, destroying 60% of buildings on both the French and Dutch sides of this island.
After Hurricane Maria brought extensive damage to Puerto Rico, this mayor of San Juan has publicly criticized the Trump Administration’s disaster relief efforts.
Odysseus and his men encounter one of these creatures in a cave, a one-eyed giant named Polyphemus.
After passing the sirens, Odysseus inched his way between the monster Scylla and this monster, a giant whirlpool with teeth.
On the island of these cannibal giants, Odysseus loses all his ships except for his own, as well as most of his men.
Name this play set in Grover’s Corners that is narrated by the Stage Manager.
This author of The Matchmaker, The Skin of Our Teeth, and The Bridge of San Luis Rey wrote Our Town.
This character in Our Town is the town drunk and choir director. He eventually commits suicide.
Name this system of discriminatory anti-black laws which governed South Africa from 1948 to 1991.
This organization opposed Apartheid and is now South Africa’s largest political party. Nelson Mandela led Spear of the Nation, this organization’s militant wing.
This South African President legalized the ANC in 1990 and released Mandela from prison, sparking the end of Apartheid.
Perhaps the most well-known painting of our first president is this Emanuel Leutze work showing Washington crossing an icy before the Battle of Trenton.
This artist's Daughters of Revolution shows three old women standing in front of Washington Crossing the Delaware. Another painting by this man used Nan Wood Graham and Byron McKeeby as models.
This other Grant Wood painting shows Washington cutting down his father's cherry tree and takes its name in part from that myth’s author.
Name these properties that depend on the number of solute particles in a solution, but not the identity of the solute.
This colligative property is the amount of pressure needed to stop the inward flow of the solvent across a membrane. It is equal to MRT times the van ‘t Hoff factor, i.
This is the van ‘t Hoff factor of glucose, as it is a non-electrolyte.
Name this novel about Oskar Matzerath, a boy who decides to stop growing at the age of three and has a scream that can shatter glass.
This author wrote The Tin Drum in addition to its sequels, Cat and Mouse and The Dog Years.
This other novel by Grass is loosely based on the fable The Fisherman and His Wife. Grass himself said that “women’s libbers” were offended by this novel.

answers: “Symphony of a Thousand” (accept “Sinfonie der Tausend”; or Symphony No. 8 by Mahler)
The Song of the Earth (accept Das Lied von der Erde)
parts: This work is named for how many players are seemingly on the stage, although very few orchestrations actually use that many.
This composer wrote “Symphony of a Thousand,” although he did not sanction that nickname for the piece.
This work by Mahler combines the song cycle and symphony formats. It was not numbered as a symphony because of Mahler’s attempts to avoid “the curse of the ninth.”
Name this dubiously ethical experiment which used classical conditioning to make a child associate loud noises with furry objects.
This American psychologist conducted the Little Albert experiment as well as the Kerplunk experiment.
Watson’s Kerplunk experiment measured this type of learning in rats as they ran through a maze.
Name this theorem that gives the maximum number of colors needed to fill a map without adjacent countries having the same color. This theorem was proved using a computer.
A statement of the four color theorem using graph theory has one of these objects in each country. They are connected by arcs or edges in directed and undirected graphs.
If a graph H can be formed by contracting edges on graph G, H is one of these constructs. These objects are formed by deleting edges while merging vertices of a source graph.
Name this feminist essay by Virginia Woolf, originally given as a series of lectures, which discusses how gender roles have robbed the world of literature.

In this feminist Woolf novel, the title character is born an Elizabethan nobleman but winds up living for hundreds of years. Many of this novel’s central characters, including the titular figure, are gender non-conforming.
This other work by Virginia Woolf follows a woman named Clarissa as she plans a party. This novel examines the role of wealth in shaping feminist characteristics.
This dance is often performed at Jewish weddings and bar and bat mitzvahs. The modern style of this dance was pioneered by Israeli dancer Baruch Agadati.
These Sufi mystics are known for their namesake rapid motion which is performed as dhikr, or remembrance of God.

Wovoka, a Paiute spiritual leader, sparked this movement-based social movement which spread to many Native American tribes in 1889 and 1890. This religious movement led to a namesake war between the Sioux and the US.

answers: index of refraction (accept refractive index, accept n)
squared (accept raising to the second power or equivalents)
parts: Name this quantity, the ratio of the speed of light in a vacuum to the speed of light in a material.
This doubly-eponymous equation relates the refractive index or dielectric constant of a material to polarizability.
Malus’s law states that the intensity of completely plane-polarized light is proportional to this function of the cosine of the angle between the transmission axes and the polarizer.

answers: Charlemagne (accept Charles I, Charles the Great, or Carolus Magnus)
parts: This eighteenth century English historian argued that Christianity hastened the title event of his Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire.
In a namesake thesis, Henri Pirenne argues that the Muslim conquests enabled this man’s Western European empire to prosper. This uncle of Roland became the first Holy Roman Emperor in 800 AD.
This impactful 1893 thesis claims that American values and priorities were indelibly shaped by western expansion.
Name this 1759 satirical work by Voltaire.
Candide is in love with this daughter of Baron Thunder-ten-Tronckh. She is later part of a sharing agreement between the Grand Inquisitor and Don Issachar.
This man is Candide’s valet while he is in the Americas and accompanies him to the kingdom of El Dorado.

This 2.5 acre section of the park is dedicated to the memory of John Lennon and contains the “Imagine” mosaic. It takes its name from a Liverpool children’s home featured in the title of a Lennon song.
This large boulder in the southwest portion of Central Park is a popular tourist destination. This outcrop is named for the hordes of vermin that used to inhabit it at night.

Central Park contains this woman’s namesake needle, in fact a giant obelisk constructed by Pharaoh Thutmose III. The obelisk was originally housed near a temple this woman built to honor her lover Marc Antony.
Name this woodwind instrument played by Charlie Parker and Kenny G.
The improvisational style of this saxophonist was termed "sheets of sound" by Ira Gitler. He recorded the albums Blue Train and A Love Supreme.
Coltrane occasionally performed as a sideman for this jazz pianist who composed the standards “Round Midnight” and “Straight, No Chaser.”

answers: transposons (accept jumping genes, transposable elements, or TEs)
parts: Name these segments of DNA that make up 44% of the human genome. The first of these to be discovered was the Ac/Ds system.
This cytogeneticist won the 1983 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for her discovery of transposition.
McClintock discovered transposons in these plants, whose lack of digestible niacin causes pellagra. Most of the “flint” type of this cereal grain has multicolored kernels.
Name this German trading federation which dominated maritime commerce in Northern Europe during the High Middle Ages.
The Hanseatic League primarily operated in this body of water, bounded by the North Sea and the Gulf of Bothnia. In this sea, the Hanse were often targeted by the Victual Brothers piracy guild.
This port city was known as the “Queen of the Hanseatic League” for being the organization’s most prominent member. This city was the first to be firebombed by the RAF during World War II.

In the voodoo religion, a possession by the spirit Ogoun emulates the effects of this other type of spirit, a drink made from sugar cane that traveled across the world during the Atlantic slave trade.
This lion goddess of ancient Egypt was only stopped from wiping out humanity when the gods tricked her into getting drunk by making her think wine was blood.
When a surprise cadre of a cardinals needed refreshment, this woman took water out of a bathtub which miraculously changed into beer as the guests began to drink.
